ground_truth: We're given that $\triangle ABQ \sim \triangle QCP$ and thus $m\angle B = m\angle C.$ Therefore, $\triangle ABC$ is isosceles. From the given $m\angle BAC=70^\circ$, we have that $m\angle ABC = m\angle BCA = 55^\circ$.  But we also know that $\triangle ABC \sim \triangle PAQ$, which means that $m\angle PAQ=55^\circ$ as well.  Subtracting, $m\angle BAQ=15^\circ$.  Finally, from similar triangles, we have $m\angle PQC=m\angle BAQ = \boxed{15^\circ}$.

inference:

From $\triangle ABQ$, $\angle AQB = 180^\circ - (\angle ABQ + \angle BAQ) = 180^\circ - (x + 70^\circ) = 110^\circ - x$.
From $\triangle QCP$, $\angle CQP = 180^\circ - (\angle QCP + \angle CPQ) = 180^\circ - (x + \angle CPQ)$.
Since $\angle PQA + \angle AQB = 180^\circ$, and $\angle AQB = 110^\circ - x$. Then
$180^\circ - (\angle AQB) = 180^\circ - (110^\circ - x) = 70^\circ + x$.

Since $\angle QCP = \angle QPC$, $\angle PQA = \angle ABQ = x$.

$\angle AQP + \angle APQ = \angle AQB = 110^\circ - x$. Also, $\angle QCP = x$
In $\triangle QCP$, $\angle CQP + \angle CPQ + \angle QCP = 180^\circ$.
By exterior angle theorem in quadrilateral $ABQP$, $\angle ABQ + \angle PQA = 180^\circ$.
$\angle ABQ + x = 180^\circ$.
$x + 70 + \angle PQA = 180 \Rightarrow \angle PQA = 110 - x$.
In $\triangle ABC \sim \triangle PAQ$, we have $\angle BAC = \angle PAQ = 70^\circ$. In $\triangle ABQ \sim \triangle QCP$, we have $\angle ABQ = \angle QCP = x$.
$x + (110-x) = 110^\circ$.
$\boxed{110}$
